title: Atheism can be just as toxic as any religious community

author: Thesilphsecret
text:
You haven't demonstrated that atheism can be as toxic as any religion, you've only demonstrated that their are toxic atheists.

Well -- yeah -- obviously.  People don't just stop being toxic because they haven't been convinced a God exists.

Atheism isn't toxic at all, not even 1%.  It's just the concept of not believing a God exists.  There's no book of rules or expectations or standard of morals or anything.  It's no more toxic than not believing Pro Wrestling is real.

Does that mean somebody can't be a toxic jerk about how fake wrestling is?  Of course.  People are toxic.

However, your post doesn't demonstrate anything about atheism being toxic.  You're just talking about individual atheists who are acting on their own impulses and preferences and emotions and sense of ethics.  None of that can be blamed on atheism.

However, when a Christian parent disowns their gay child, this *CAN* be blamed on Christianity.  When a wife is treated like property, this *CAN* be blamed on Christianity.  When somebody goes to another country and kidnaps a bunch of people to beat and enslave, this *CAN* be blamed on Christianity.  When somebody fails to wash their hands before preparing food, this *CAN* be blamed on Christianity.

I'm not necessarily aware of a religion that doesn't have some type of text associated with it, which tells people how they're supposed to act.  As far as I can tell, that's a feature in just about every single religion.  To some degree.  However, atheism has exactly zero degree of that.  It's just a word we use to describe somebody who *doesn't* follow an alleged holy book.  And there's nothing whatsoever toxic about not following an alleged holy book.

It says that they deserve death, and that it is the responsibility of their community to put them to death in order to purge evil from amongst them.  You're right, though -- it doesn't say to disown them, merely to consider them an abomination and put them to death.

However, most Christians are like the rest of us, in that they are aware that they will go to prison if they kill someone, and in that they have an extreme aversion to killing their own chidlren (or anybody else, for that matter).  So instead of taking their children outside and gathering the town to throw rocks at their faces until they die of brain damage, they just disown them.

Fun fact -- while people commonly say that the Bible doesn't actually say anything about trans people, it *does* specifically say that God detests anyone who wears clothing inteneded for the opposite gender.  So there's a Biblical basis for transphobia as well.

> Christianity doesn’t command people to no wash hands.

You're right, it doesn't -- Jesus just yells at the Pharisees for washing their hands before they eat.  He tells them that anyone who washes their hands before they eat is a fool because nothing that goes into your mouth can make you unclean.  He also goes on to chastise them for failing to kill their own children, and basically says "no wonder your children are so rude and disrespectful, you guys don't kill your children when they disobey." author: Thesilphsecret
text:
>  it doesn’t say that either.

Kind of weird to assert that a book that big *doesn't* say something.  Do you have the whole thing committed to memory?  See, if somebody told me the Bible said something I didn't think it said, I wouldn't simply assert that it didn't say so -- I would ask them *where* it says that (especially if the conversation were taking place in a debate forum).  This way, if I'm wrong, I don't look like a fool; meanwhile, if I'm *right,* then *they* end up looking like a fool.

I'll be sure to include the *entire* passage, so I'm not accused of taking anything out of context.

Romans 1:18-32 *God's Wrath Against Sinful Humanity*

> The wrath of God is being revealed from heaven against all the godlessness and wickedness of people, who suppress the truth by their wickedness, since what may be known about God is plain to them, because God has made it plain to them. For since the creation of the world God’s invisible qualities—his eternal power and divine nature—have been clearly seen, being understood from what has been made, so that people are without excuse.

> For although they knew God, they neither glorified him as God nor gave thanks to him, but their thinking became futile and their foolish hearts were darkened. Although they claimed to be wise, they became fools and exchanged the glory of the immortal God for images made to look like a mortal human being and birds and animals and reptiles.

> Therefore God gave them over in the sinful desires of their hearts to sexual impurity for the degrading of their bodies with one another. They exchanged the truth about God for a lie, and worshiped and served created things rather than the Creator—who is forever praised. Amen.

> Because of this, God gave them over to shameful lusts. Even their women exchanged natural sexual relations for unnatural ones. In the same way the men also abandoned natural relations with women and were inflamed with lust for one another. Men committed shameful acts with other men, and received in themselves the due penalty for their error.

> Furthermore, just as they did not think it worthwhile to retain the knowledge of God, so God gave them over to a depraved mind, so that they do what ought not to be done. They have become filled with every kind of wickedness, evil, greed and depravity. They are full of envy, murder, strife, deceit and malice. They are gossips, slanderers, God-haters, insolent, arrogant and boastful; they invent ways of doing evil; they disobey their parents; they have no understanding, no fidelity, no love, no mercy. Although they know God’s righteous decree that those who do such things deserve death, they not only continue to do these very things but also approve of those who practice them.

As you can see, it says exactly what I alleged it did.  Why would I make up something so specific?  Also, there's Leviticus 20:13, but I'm sure you're well aware of that one, and would probably just chalk it up to an old covenant.  No need to go down that path, we can stay focused on Romans as it is in the New Testament.

> no, that’s not what happened. They were critiquing Jesus and his apostles for washing to their wrist, when they washed to elbows. Jesus then pointed out that washing hands doesn’t determine holiness, but what’s in the heart does.

I'm unfamiliar with it saying Jesus washed his hands up to his wrist.  I cannot find this portion of the Bible.  Can you please provide the exact text which says that Jesus washed his hands up to his wrist?

Either way, he still said that anyone who thinks something going into your mouth can defile you or make you unclean is dull and that the Pharisees have offended God by failing to kill their children.

I'm much less interested in whether or not Jesus wanted Christians to refrain from washing their hands and much more interested in why you don't think the Bible says to kill gay people, when it so obviously does.

You know that you can just say you disagree with the Bible -- right?  Like you're not obligated to make everything in it fit your own personal sense of ethics.  You can just say that you disagree with some of the things it says.  There's no reason you have to agree with everything or even anything it says.  Cause like -- it says what it says.  Choosing to twist it's words and meaning into unrecognizable forms isn't going to fool the people who wrote it... I don't see why people can't just say "Yeah you're right actually, the Bible does say that -- that's pretty horrendous and I don't agree with it."

Where in U.S history do you see people traveling to other lands and enslaving them because of Christianity? Nobody would be enslaving people if it did not bring significant material benefits to themselves. This can be seen in many ways. For instance, the Catholic Church condemned to enslavement of natives by the Spanish on many occasions, with Pope Paul III issuing 3 Papal Bulls against such practices. Advocacy from the clergy led to the "New Laws" in 1542, which officially ended slavery of Indians. These laws were a failure however, as they were impossible to enforce due to extreme hostility. There were attacks on clergy and even Spanish officials who attempted to enforce such laws.  In these cases, we can see that even with Papal and Church condemnation of the practice, along with religious and monastic orders working against such practices, people still engaged in slavery because it was so beneficial to them materially.

author: Thesilphsecret
text:
> It was the atheist ideology of the Soviet Union that encouraged people to kill hundreds of thousands of people for holding religious beliefs

So is it fair then to say that Christians smoke a lot of weed?  Because the Rastafarians say that the reason they do it is because they're following the Biblical God.

Personally, I wouldn't blame Christianity for people smoking weed, because the book doesn't actually say to do that.  Just because one group of Christians do it doesn't mean it's necessarily encouraged by the belief system.  The Bible says to kill people for being gay, but it doesn't say to smoke weed.

Atheism doesn't have any commandments, so I don't see how this is at all equivalent.  A person can be an atheist and do anything they want.  A person can be black and do anything they want.  A person can be a Star Wars fan and do anything they want.  But if a person is a Christian they have certain rules they're expected to follow.

Therefore it makes sense to blame Christianity when a Christian does what the Christian rules say to do.  It doesn't make sense to blame blackness when a black person does what they personally want to do, and it doesn't make sense to blame atheism when an atheist does what they personally want to do.  These are different things.

> The fact that every single regime that has been explicitly atheist has also been extraordinarily murderous and tyrannical seems to suggest that there is more to atheism than just non believing in God.

Lol no it doesn't.  That's not how words work.  Atheism means you don't believe in God.  If you want to criticize something more specific, that's fine.

When Israel strayed from God, it was depicted as an adulterous woman or a prostitute. The relationship between Christ and the Church is depicted similarly, as a monogamous marriage. The New Testament and the teachings of Jesus also point towards monogamy as the only acceptable form of marriage.

>The logical leap you just made should be obvious. The fact that higher frequency of porn use was correlated with divorce does not in any way indicate that porn use causes divorce.

As study after study has shown, heavy porn use is linked to much higher rates of divorce than light porn use, which is linked to high rates of divorce than no porn use. Porn use is also linked to more relationship failure in dating relationships as well. Viewing pornography has been linked with a lower likelihood of marriage, while viewing religious sites has been linked with a higher likelihood of marriage. Study after study has shown that people who use porn report lower relationship and sexual satisfaction and contentment than those who do not use porn, while ending porn use is linked with higher relational and sexual satisfaction and contentment.  I think it should be rather obvious that watching other people have sex in order to have sexual satisfaction is not very good for a relationship.

To more directly answer the question of whether porn use is more than just correlated with relationship breakdown, it is helpful to look at many studies that have shown that relationships tend to decline in quality after one partner discovers the pornography habits of the other partner. Studies have also shown that those who use pornography are more likely to engage in adultery than those who do not. Adultery is one of the major contributing factors of divorce. Porn use is correlated with higher likelihood of cheating on a partner in a dating relationship as well, which is one of the leading factors for breakups among boyfriends and girlfriends. Other studies have shown that those who use pornography are more likely to procure prostitutes, which provides no help and much harm in relationships. From this, it seems to suggest that porn helps to encourage behaviors that negatively affect relationships, which leads to greater break ups and divorces.

>This is not true. The Bible says that you shall take your slaves from the nations that surround you, and even allows you to kidnap wives from the nations you [conquer.tl](http://conquer.tl)

The Bible contains provisions pertaining solely to the nation of Israel, allowing it to take prisoners of war from enemy nations and enslave them. It also contains provisions allowing the Israelite men to marry captive women and make them part of their family, giving them the status of Israelite women and lesser wife.

Worth noting when discussing slavery is that Israel was unique in the ancient world in its laws towards slavery, as they granted slaves many rights. A slave was to have immediate manumission should they suffer the loss or severe injury of any part of the body, even if it is just a single tooth. As far as I am aware, there were no other societies in history in which slaves were to be granted immediate freedom for what would often be considered minor injuries. Slaves also had the right to not work on the Sabbath. Not many cultures give their slaves a mandatory day of rest from work and duties.

We can also look at laws forbidding the murder of slaves, meaning slaves had the right to life, which is not something most slaves had in most cultures. It is hard to find any other culture where a master could be executed for killing a slave. Slaves also had the right to sexual integrity, in the sense that it was forbidden to rape a slave, it was forbidden to engage in fornication with a slave, and it was forbidden to commit adultery with a slaves wife. These laws mandate respect for a slaves marriage, family, and bodily integrity. Kidnapping a person and selling them into slavery was also forbidden. This crime was punished by execution, and applied to instances of Israelites kidnapping anybody, whether they are a fellow Israelite or a foreigner.

All of this is simply touching the surface and does not go into deeper theological arguments as to why slavery is impermissible.
